faq.question: Can experience truly be expressed in words?

answers.Ender:
SR as a concept is quite literally impossible to talk about with words. While the statement "I am consciousness" is true, it gets presented as a belief which is not what SR is.

The concept of consciousness is the best possible abstraction of what you are, but it is still ultimately not successful because understanding the concept does not lead to an actual literal understanding of being the consciousness. Trying to communicate what the "true self" is, is kind of like trying to communicate to someone who doesn't speak English what blue is. They absolutely have direct experience of what it is, but merely saying the word can't directly communicate what you mean since "the word is not the thing."

The quality of the self's "nothingness" never changes. The whole problem is that I can't describe it to you because it's not describable. It is more like a unique observation. You can tell people to look in their direct experience but they have no idea where to look. When you say words they focus on the meaning of the words because that's how words work, but that's not where the insight is.
answers.Jamie: In my experience, nearly all of feelings of "I wanted to express something but I couldn't" is usually related to thinking. It is, in my experience, basically impossible to have any sensory experience that can't be communicated in basic thought other than other thought.
answers.Capy:
You experience taste, but you don't experience the word which describes the taste. You have to remember your knowledge of words and experiences to find the word that describes the taste, that is the only part that memory plays. You are using memory to find a word which describes something that is not memory.

Thoughts don't represent things, they are the things they represent. It's a self-contained perception, exactly like seeing, hearing, touching, etc. There's nothing outside the thought being represented. Just like you can't see something outside of seeing.
answers.holos:
Thought is not really made up of anything, thought simply references other thoughts (concepts). For example, the concept of a fridge requires a reference of possibly a rectangle, maybe even your own fridge and you ascribe characteristics to that like the concept of 2 doors, metal casing, the food inside etc. Fridge as a thought is simply a reference or a pointer to that extraction of experience via memory.

Pointers from thought only point to themselves, there's nothing outside of consciousness ever.
answers.will:
Thought cannot ever contain the totality of what life is, because thought is a subset of it. Thought's attempt to capture a wholistic experience is negated by the fact that thought can only reference what has been accumulated through time, and can never be quick enough to grasp what's happening now.

I can intellectually understand that you are referring to a particular object when you say car, but I don't confuse the word 'car' for the thing being directly perceived.

The characteristics you're imagining aren't features of 'you'. A thought can never physically alter reality, even if you could argue someone's conceptualisation of something is 'closer to reality' it still isn't and never will be reality.
answers.Gabriel:
Yes, but there will always be information loss.

There currently exists no language that perfectly captures experience. The closest would probably be poetry.

answers.Ender:
Where do thoughts come from? If you realize you don't really have a solid answer to that question I don't see how you could be in control of them. You don't have control over your thoughts to the same degree that you don't have control over what you see, hear, or any other sense. Even if you close your eyes, you're looking at your eyelids. Thought is just another sense perception.

There is this old Eastern teaching that I found helpful: You are not your mind. Rephrasing it, there is literally no difference between someone telling you something, and thinking something to yourself. Both cases are an observation of a thought from a source that is not you. Realizing that you are not the one generating the thoughts makes self-inquiry far easier.

What causes the brain to create the thought? Really my only line of reasoning is that if you keep asking "why did you do that" enough times about any action eventually you find a cause that is surely outside of your control.
answers.Jamie: The point to be made is that there is no first principle, which originates itself in thought, where does that thought come from? From where does that symbol or identification originate other than thought, and what is that?
answers.Capy:
Get really good at watching your thoughts appear and disappear in whatever capacity. What does it look like for a thought to disappear? What does it feel like?

Really focus on your mind's capacity to describe things. What is it describing? How is it describing? What is a description? Can I describe something without thinking?

Just take notice of this innate capability of your mind, which is that it appears as things and then stops appearing as them. And also notice that your emotions appear and disappear alongside them. The cause of the emotion is not what the thought is describing, it is how the thought feels currently.
answers.holos:
Thought is a divisory experience. Just look at any thought right now whether it's a description or a label. "Pink Elephants" - you've never seen one but you're thinking of one now. What is that thought right there, it's simply a division of the color pink and an animal thus some imagined object.

Thinking is not something to be scared or judgemental about. Thinking is thinking and it's happening now so there's nothing to fear about it.
answers.will:
Thought is a mechanism in the brain, it is a process that we can understand. Thought is limited, and anything it creates is limited. Thought can only operate in a limited field of knowledge consisting of things it has collected.

Thought is a circuit, it will continually repeat. Thought is stuck on a train track circuit. Even if it moves further down the line and has supposedly found something new, it is still operating within the same limits.

Thought is like sand and is constantly sprinkling itself onto the ocean to draw a pretty image. As pretty as the sandcastle is, it's gotta fall. Thought as a material process cannot EVER under any circumstance be permanent or be secure.
answers.Gabriel: Sensory experience creates memory, and memory creates thought.

faq.question: Why don't you need a self-image?

Having a construct of a "me" is absolutely very useful when navigating social situations. However, mistaking the construct for literally being "me" causes a lot of unnecessary suffering. It's not that having a construct is unnecessary, but literally recognizing a "me" inside of that construct is unnecessary. You are not the construct. You are the awareness of sensory perception.
answers.Jamie: The reason you don't need a self-image is because you don't need to imagine who you are. You are experiencing what you are every single moment of your life right now.
answers.Capy:

In the same way how there is no way to get rid of Santa Claus, there is only realizing that he isn't in your experience already. It's already the case. It's already inherent to your experience.
answers.holos:

answers.Gabriel:

answers.holos:

answers.Gabriel:

answers.will:

faq.question: What is the root of discontent?

answers.Ender:

We are disappointed because we make comparisons. However, the choice of what comparison we decide to make somehow manages to be, more often than not, comparing what you believe your present circumstance to be with an imaginary way things could have gone better. In that moment the disappointment comes from the comparison and not from the literal direct experience of what happened. Ultimately all psychological suffering is comparison that gets dressed in fancier and fancier clothes.

The mind makes selective comparisons that often lead to suffering. Why does someone with body dysmorphia compare their body to someone who they believe has an attractive body far more than they compare their body to unattractive bodies? Paying attention to those comparisons and making different strategic comparisons can alleviate some, if not all of the suffering from comparison.
answers.Jamie: It's a relationship with your past, present and future. You feel discontent in the present because there is a previous "wrong" or "insufficiency" you want to correct, improve or achieve. This creates a present demand in the brain to acquire, achieve, or overcome something.
answers.Capy:

The belief that knowledge comes from past and future means you will search the past and future for information about yourself and that information you pull out about yourself is self-image.
answers.holos:
We are not looking for solution, by seeking a solution you're just painting an image of how you fall short and there is something to solve. Your actual relationship with time is absolutely non-existent. You have suddenly been placed in this body with all of its functions and memories right now.

It seems quite reasonable that the past exists. Right now I remember there being an experience of breakfast this morning.
